title: Tachographs - rules for drivers and operators

table.body:
Tachographs record information about driving time, speed and distance. They're used to make sure drivers and employers follow the rules on [drivers' hours](/drivers-hours "Read about the rules on drivers' hours").

##Do you need a tachograph?

You must use a tachograph if the vehicle you're driving comes under EU or AETR rules. 

^Find out if EU or AETR rules apply to the [passenger carrying vehicle](/drivers-hours/passenger-carrying-vehicles "Find out if EU or AETR rules apply if you drive a passenger-carrying vehicle") or [goods vehicle](/drivers-hours/goods-vehicles "Find out if EU or AETR rules apply to your goods vehicle") that you're driving.^

###Exemptions

You don't have to use a tachograph if your vehicle isn't covered by EU rules or if it's [exempt from EU rules on drivers’ hours](/drivers-hours/exemptions-from-eu-law "find out if your vehicle is exempt from EU rules on drivers' hours").

##Types of tachograph

There are 2 types of tachograph - analogue and digital.

^All commercial vehicles first registered on or after 1 May 2006 must be fitted with digital tachographs. Otherwise you can use an analogue tachograph.^

##Further information

The Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) has detailed guides to drivers' hours and tachographs for good vehicles and passenger carrying vehicles (PCVs). They include the rules on:

- analogue tachographs - including proper record keeping and filling in centrefold entries
- digital tachographs - including using drivers' cards, lost, stolen or faulty cards, setting the time and manual record keeping
- common rules for all tachographs - including 'multi-manning' and keeping 2nd driver records, recording other work, rest-days and days off
- responsibilities of operators - including calibrating and maintaining tachograph equipment
- what happens if you don't follow the rules

$D

[Download 'The Rules on Drivers' Hours and Tachographs - Goods Vehicles' (PDF, 4.6MB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Rules%20on%20Drivers%20Hours%20and%20Tachographs%20-%20Goods%20Vehicles%20in%20GB%20and%20Europe.pdf "Download 'The Rules on Drivers' Hours and Tachographs - Goods Vehicles' (PDF, 4.6MB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

$D

[Download 'The Rules on Drivers' Hours and Tachographs - Passenger-carrying Vehicles' (PDF, 4.4MB)](http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Rules%20on%20Drivers%20Hours%20and%20Tachographs%20-%20PSVs%20in%20GB%20and%20Europe.pdf "Download 'The Rules on Drivers' Hours and Tachographs - Passenger-carrying Vehicles' (PDF, 4.4MB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

*[AETR]: European Agreement Concerning the Work of Crews of Vehicles Engaged in International Road Transport
*[PCV]: Passenger Carrying Vehicle
*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency

table.body:
If you use a smaller vehicle (eg a 4x4) for towing, you'll only need a tachograph if its total weight is more than 3.5 tonnes.

##Fitting a tachograph

The Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) has guidance on where you can fit a tachograph unit in a vehicle.

$D 

[Download 'VOSA guidance on where to fit a tachograph' (PDF, 235KB)]( http://www.dft.gov.uk/vosa/repository/Guide%20to%20acceptable%20fitment%20location.pdf "Download 'VOSA guidance on where to fit a tachograph' (PDF, 235KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

##Buying or leasing a vehicle

If you buy or lease a vehicle and it comes under the [EU or AETR rules on drivers' hours](/drivers-hours "EU or AETR rules on drivers' hours") you'll need to make sure it's designed to have a tachograph fitted.

If you've already bought a vehicle and are having problems fitting it with a tachograph call VOSA. They can tell you where your nearest Approved Tachograph Centre is. The Tachograph Centre can give you advice and help you get it fitted. It's not always possible to fit a tachograph, however.

$C

**VOSA**  
0300 123 9000  
Monday to Friday, 7:30am to 6pm 

$C

##Further help

For further information about fitting tachographs in light vehicles email the VOSA tachograph section.

$C

**VOSA tachograph section**  
<tachosection@vosa.gov.uk>

$C

*[VOSA]: Vehicle and Operator Services Agency
*[AETR]: European Agreement Concerning the Work of Crews of Vehicles Engaged in International Road Transport
